content:
1. Conwy Castle - One of the most iconic castles in Wales, Conwy Castle was built by Edward I in the 13th century.

2. Caernarfon Castle - Built by King Edward I, Caernarfon Castle is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and was the birthplace of Prince Charles, the current Prince of Wales.

3. Harlech Castle - One of the most impressive castles in North Wales, Harlech Castle was built in the 13th century.

4. Beaumaris Castle - Built in the 13th century, the unfinished Beaumaris Castle is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the most impressive examples of medieval architecture in Wales.

5. Criccieth Castle - This ruined castle sits on a rocky headland overlooking the sea, and was built by Llywelyn the Great in the 13th century.

6. Plas Mawr - A beautifully preserved Elizabethan townhouse in the heart of Conwy, Plas Mawr is a must-visit for lovers of Tudor architecture.

7. Bodnant Garden - One of the most beautiful gardens in Wales, Bodnant Garden features formal lawns, terraces, and a wide variety of plants and flowers.

8. Aberconwy House - This 14th-century merchant's house in Conwy is one of the oldest surviving buildings in Wales, and is now a museum showcasing the town's history and culture.

9. St Asaph Cathedral - This beautiful cathedral in the city of St Asaph dates back to the 13th century and is home to a stunning collection of stained glass windows.

10. Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch - While not strictly speaking a historical site, this idyllic village on the island of Anglesey is famous for having the longest place name in Europe.
